knowledge.title: Overfitting
knowledge.content: In mathematical modeling, overfitting is the production of an analysis that corresponds too closely or exactly to a particular set of data, and may therefore fail to fit to additional data or predict future observations reliably. An overfitted model is a mathematical model that contains more parameters than can be justified by the data. In the special case of a model that consists of a polynomial function, these parameters represent the degree of a polynomial. The essence of overfitting is to un

knowledge.title: ML | Underfitting and Overfitting - GeeksforGeeks
knowledge.content: Underfitting and Overfitting When a model is too simple, like fitting a straight line to curved data, it has high bias and fails to capture the true relationship, leading to underfitting. For example, a linear model cannot represent a non-linear increase in house prices with size.

knowledge.title: What is underfitting? - IBM
knowledge.content: Underfitting occurs when a model is too simple, which can be a result of a model needing more training time, more input features, or less regularization. Like overfitting, when a model is underfitted, it cannot establish the dominant trend within the data, resulting in training errors and poor performance of the model.

knowledge.content: Learn what underfitting and overfitting are, how to detect them, and how to cure them in machine learning. knowledge.title: Utilitarianism
knowledge.content: In ethical philosophy, utilitarianism is a family of normative ethical theories that prescribe actions that maximize happiness and well-being for the affected individuals. In other words, utilitarian ideas encourage actions that lead to the greatest good for the greatest number. Although different varieties of utilitarianism admit different characterizations, the basic idea that underpins them all is, in some sense, to maximize utility, which is often defined in terms of well-being or related concepts. For instance, Jeremy Bentham, the founder of utilitarianism, described utility as the capacity of actions or objects to produce benefits, such as pleasure, happiness, and good, or to prevent harm, such as pain and unhappiness, to those affected.

knowledge.title: Utilitarianism | Definition, Philosophy, Examples, Ethics, Philosophers ...
knowledge.content: Utilitarianism, in normative ethics, a tradition stemming from the late 18th- and 19th-century English philosophers and economists Jeremy Bentham and John Stuart Mill according to which an action is right if it tends to promote happiness and wrong if it tends to produce the reverse of happiness.

knowledge.title: Utilitarianism - Wikipedia
knowledge.content: Utilitarianism is a version of consequentialism, which states that the consequences of any action are the only standard of right and wrong. Unlike other forms of consequentialism, such as egoism and altruism, egalitarian utilitarianism considers either the interests of all humanity or all sentient beings equally.

knowledge.title: Unix
knowledge.content: Unix is a family of multitasking, multi-user computer operating systems that derive from the original AT&T Unix, whose development started in 1969 at the Bell Labs research center by Ken Thompson, Dennis Ritchie, and others. Initially intended for use inside the Bell System, AT&T licensed Unix to outside parties in the late 1970s, leading to a variety of both academic and commercial Unix variants from vendors including University of California, Berkeley (BSD), Microsoft (Xenix), Sun Microsystems (SunOS/Solaris), HP/HPE (HP-UX), and IBM (AIX).

knowledge.title: UNIX | Definition, Meaning, History, & Facts | Britannica
knowledge.content: UNIX, multiuser computer operating system. In the late 20th century UNIX was widely used for Internet servers, workstations, and mainframe computers. knowledge.title: Urbanization
knowledge.content: Urbanization is the population shift from rural to urban areas, the corresponding decrease in the proportion of people living in rural areas, and the ways in which societies adapt to this change. It can also mean population growth in urban areas instead of rural ones. It is predominantly the process by which towns and cities are formed and become larger as more people begin to live and work in central areas.

knowledge.content: Urbanization, the process by which large numbers of people become permanently concentrated in relatively small areas, forming cities. Explore the key concepts, theories and methods used by urban sociologists to examine social, economic, cultural and environmental issues in urban environments.

knowledge.title: What is Urban Sociology? History, Concepts, and Examples
knowledge.content: Urban sociology is the study of cities and urban life from a sociological perspective. Learn about its history, major concepts, and current issues, such as urbanization, gentrification, and sustainability.

knowledge.title: Urban Sociology - an overview | ScienceDirect Topics
knowledge.content: Urban sociology is defined as the study that describes and interprets the causal connections between the elements of a city and the factors that give rise to them, providing insights into the complexities of urban life, social structures, and the evolution of human settlements.

knowledge.title: Understanding Urban Sociology and Community Dynamics
knowledge.content: Urban sociology examines these intricate relationships between people and their city environments. When sociologists study urban spaces, they are not just looking at buildings and streets. They are exploring how these physical structures influence social behavior, community formation, and individual identity. The field reveals that cities are far more than collections of concrete and steel ...
